channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Ukraine’s Counteroffensive Forces Face Mobilized Inmates and Drones
item.description: Ukraine has been pushing a counteroffensive in the east and south, applying greater pressure to Russian forces, but there is no indication of any mass Russian withdrawal.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Marc Santora and Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier in front of a hotel in Kramatorsk on Sunday. It was struck by a Russian missile overnight.

item.title: The Singular Offense of the Mass Grave
item.description: Violent loss is even more devastating when the dead are disposed of without identification. When Russians pull out in Ukraine, they leave a trail of anonymous death.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Numbers, not names, on makeshift grave markers near Izium last week.

item.title: Guest List for Queen Elizabeth’s Funeral Includes Everyday Honorees
item.description: Among those invited to Queen Elizabeth II’s funeral are almost 200 people who were honored for various forms of public service this year.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain

item.title: Queen Elizabeth II Funeral: Schedule of Events for the Day
item.description: The funeral for Queen Elizabeth II will begin at 11 a.m. on Monday, followed by a procession across central London.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Queen Elizabeth II has been lying in state at Westminster Hall since Wednesday. A procession will accompany the queen’s coffin from Westminster Hall to Westminster Abbey on Monday morning.

item.title: Hurricane Fiona Knocks Out Power in Rain-Soaked Puerto Rico
item.description: Fiona, which made landfall on Sunday afternoon, led to significant flooding and could bring two and a half feet of rain in parts of Puerto Rico, forecasters said.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Flooding caused by Hurricane Fiona in Cayey, Puerto Rico, on Sunday. Forecasters said as much as 30 inches of rain could fall in some places.

item.title: In Recovery After Storm, Alaska Faces Hard Days Ahead
item.description: Geography and climate add to the challenges for the hard-hit isolated communities as the cold months draw closer.
item.dc:creator: Emily Schwing
item.media:description: The storm over the weekend was one of the worst to hit Alaska in decades.

item.title: How Russian Trolls Helped Keep the Women’s March Out of Lock Step
item.description: As American feminists came together in 2017 to protest Donald Trump, Russia’s disinformation machine set about deepening the divides among them.
item.dc:creator: Ellen Barry

item.title: After Texas Sent Him to Washington, One Migrant Launches a New Life
item.description: Lever Alejos, who was delivered to the nation’s capital courtesy of Gov. Greg Abbott, has found plenty of work. ‘I feel fortunate the governor put me on a bus to Washington.’
item.dc:creator: Miriam Jordan
item.media:credit: Oliver Contreras for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lever Alejos, 29, is one of a record number of Venezuelans crossing the southern border into the United States, seeking asylum and hoping to build permanent lives in America.

item.title: Las Vegas Aces Beat Sun for First WNBA Championship
item.description: The Aces shook off their reputation for being better in the regular season by holding off several rallies by the Sun.
item.dc:creator: Kris Rhim
item.media:description: A'ja Wilson, the franchise player of the Las Vegas Aces, celebrating winning the W.N.B.A. championship on Sunday.

item.title: Drownings at Coney Island Mark the End of a Mother’s Descent
item.description: Erin Merdy, who is charged with killing her three children, had struggled with money, men and mental health. Now, she is accused of one of New York’s worst crimes against children in recent memory.
item.dc:creator: Corey Kilgannon and Chelsia Rose Marcius
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: The small victims were remembered in a vigil on the Coney Island boardwalk on Thursday.

item.title: Clearview AI, Used by Police to Find Criminals, Now in Public Defenders’ Hands
item.description: After a Florida man was accused of vehicular homicide, his lawyer used Clearview AI’s facial recognition software to prove his innocence. But other defense lawyers say Clearview’s offer rings hollow.
item.dc:creator: Kashmir Hill
item.category: National Assn of Criminal Defense Lawyers
item.media:credit: Scott McIntyre for The New York Times
item.media:description: The police believed Andrew Grantt Conlyn had been driving during a car crash that killed his friend. Facial recognition software helped find the man who knew he had been in the passenger’s seat.

item.title: How Yiyun Li Became a Beacon for Readers in Mourning
item.description: The novelist Yiyun Li, known for her powerful distillations of personal grief, makes art from subverted expectations.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Kleeman
item.media:credit: Naila Ruechel for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yiyun Li at home in Princeton, New Jersey.

item.title: What Joe Biden Knows That No One Expected Him To
item.description: A liberalism that is as ambitious about solving problems through invention as it is through redistribution would be powerful indeed.
item.dc:creator: Ezra Klein
item.category: Advanced Research Projects Agency for Health
item.media:credit: Illustration by Frank Augugliaro; Photograph by EyeEm/Getty Images

item.title: Humans Have a Long History of Making ‘Very Bad Decisions’ to Save Animals
item.description: As scientists push the frontiers of conservation technology, some of their initiatives raise ethical questions.
item.dc:creator: Tim McDonnell

item.title: The Return of Combat Joe
item.description: President Biden’s combative side comes out periodically. That’s when he’s at his best.
item.dc:creator: Charles M. Blow

item.title: Our Memory Is Flawed. Luckily, God’s Isn’t.
item.description: What a parent’s dementia reveals about God and humanity.
item.dc:creator: Tish Harrison Warren

item.title: How Low Can Republicans Go?
item.description: G.O.P. grapes of wrath at Martha’s Vineyard.
item.dc:creator: Maureen Dowd
item.media:description: A young man who was part of a group of migrants flown to Martha's Vineyard at the Florida governor’s direction.

item.title: Math Is the Great Secret
item.description: If human beings invented numbers and counting, then how is it that there are numbers such as primes that have attributes no one gave them?
item.dc:creator: Alec Wilkinson

item.title: The Quality That Sustained Queen Elizabeth Is Hobbling Putin
item.description: Why legitimacy is key for rulers.
item.dc:creator: Ross Douthat
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain

item.title: Our Assumptions About the Maternal Instinct
item.description: Readers react to an essay about how the maternal instinct is a myth. Also: A third-party alternative; the work environment; new baseball rules; billionaires.

item.title: The Sunday Read: ‘Why Do We Love TikTok Audio Memes? Call it Brainfeel’
item.description: Repurposed sound has taken over social media. Science tells us why.
item.dc:creator: Charlotte Shane, Jack D’Isidoro, Aaron Esposito, John Woo, Elisheba Ittoop and Quinton Kamara

item.title: Warnings From Authors Who Track Domestic Extremism
item.description: Luke Mogelson and Andy Campbell have followed groups like the Proud Boys for years. They are terrified at what they see as a growing threat.
item.dc:creator: Blake Hounshell
item.category: The Storm Is Here: An American Crucible (Book)
item.media:description: Rioters breaching the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, including Dominic Pezzola of the Proud Boys, center, with gray beard. A new book tracks the group’s development.

item.title: What Does Queen Elizabeth’s Death Mean for Canada?
item.description: The accession of King Charles III may inspire more discussion about the relevance of the monarchy in Canada, but materially, experts say it’s business as usual.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: King Charles III accompanied the procession taking Queen Elizabeth II’s coffin to Westminster Hall.

item.title: After Dobbs: Does ‘Big Tent’ Feminism Exist? Should It?
item.description: Anne-Marie Slaughter and Tressie McMillan Cottom on the future of the feminist movement.
item.dc:creator: ‘The Argument’

item.title: Biden Calls Trump ‘Irresponsible’ Over Mar-a-Lago Documents
item.description: Speaking to “60 Minutes,” the president also declared the Covid-19 pandemic to be “over” in the United States.
item.dc:creator: Jim Tankersley
item.media:description: President Biden in Detroit last week. In an interview, he expressed optimism over inflation and stressed falling gasoline prices.

item.title: New Boosters Test Covid-Weary Nation.Do Americans Care?
item.description: The new vaccine campaign is one of the country’s last remaining strategies, as masks have fallen away and quarantines have diminished. So far, the rollout is methodical but muted.
item.dc:creator: Jack Healy, Sharon Otterman and Amy Qin
item.media:credit: Andrew Seng for The New York Times
item.media:description: Holly Fulmer administering a new Covid booster to Ethel Brown in the Bronx.

item.title: Cameron Mackintosh on Closing of ‘Phantom of the Opera’
item.description: In an interview, the storied British producer said that weakening box office and rising production costs led to the decision to end the longest run in Broadway history.
item.dc:creator: Michael Paulson
item.media:description: “You don’t want to run a great show into the ground,” Cameron Mackintosh said.

item.title: Aaron Judge Is Chasing Roger Maris and a Triple Crown
item.description: Aaron Judge’s monster season for the Yankees has him leading the majors in home runs and runs batted in by a wide margin. A batting title would be icing on the cake.
item.dc:creator: James Wagner
item.media:credit: Jeff Hanisch/USA Today Sports, via Reuters
item.media:description: Aaron Judge of the Yankees homered twice on Sunday, putting him at 59 for the season.

item.title: How to Prepare for Flu Season
item.description: We may be more susceptible to the virus than we have been in recent years, but doctors have tips to stay healthy.
item.dc:creator: Melinda Wenner Moyer

item.title: How to Nurse a Vulnerability Hangover
item.description: That thing you shared last night? It’s probably just fine.
item.dc:creator: Holly Burns

item.title: What Parents Should Know About Enterovirus: Symptoms and Risks
item.description: The C.D.C. has issued an alert about enterovirus D68, which has been linked to rare, polio-like paralysis.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Pearson
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Kayana Szymczak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Children who experience paralysis after contracting enterovirus, like this 4-year-old boy, may need physical therapy to help rebuild strength and balance.

item.title: How Family and Friends Helped Get Me Through the Pandemic
item.description: As Covid raged, many Americans hunkered down with family members and relied on friends — and some came away with deepened relationships. Here are a few of their stories.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Needelman
item.media:credit: Cig Harvey for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rita and Jon Ellis at Lermond Pond in Maine. Mr. Ellis credits his wife for his recovery from pancreatic cancer. They are two of the many people who leaned on family and friends to help them through a difficult couple of years.

item.title: Are monkeypox scars permanent?
item.description: The best time to care for skin lesions is in their active phase.
item.dc:creator: Knvul Sheikh

item.title: Ultramarathon Runners Won’t Give Up Their Sport
item.description: Last year, the ultramarathon governing body dumped many multiday races from their catalog. So a group of fringe runners created their own championship, and just kept running.
item.dc:creator: Jared Beasley
item.media:credit: Michelle Gustafson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Race participants start the race for the first annual GOMU 48-Hour World Championships, an ultramarathon in Hainesport, N.J.
